image.altText: Four people and a police officer stand near a grey car in the driveway of a brick home with a car and couch on the frontpath.

props.synopsis: A woman remains in a critical condition in hospital after being mauled by three dogs at a home in Dandenong, in Melbourne's south-east, on Thursday.

title.children: Woman attacked by dogs in Melbourne backyard remains in critical condition

image.altText: Against a white background a hand holds a smartphone by thumb and index finger, hanging from up high.

props.synopsis: More Aussies are falling victim to an organised criminal underground selling counterfeit smartphones, designed to look and feel like the real deal.

title.children: 'Completely gutted': Aussies getting hit by criminal networks' fake phone scams

image.altText: Clayton Oliver in action for Melbourne

props.synopsis: Melbourne star Clayton Oliver appears adamant he will not play again for the club and has seemingly taken matters into his own hands. Follow live for all the updates on day five of the AFL trade period.

title.children: 'Absolute mess': Clayton Oliver's drastic move to force Melbourne's hand, as shock pick swap lights up trade period

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Melbourne not budging on Clayton Oliver at this stage

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks defiantly at the camera, while holding the handle of a shovel.

props.synopsis: Fed up with the threat of floods, Victorian resident Tuesday Browell is thought to be the first private Australian resident to import war-zone technology to protect her home.

title.children: Victorian flood victim becomes 'first private resident' to import military-grade protection system

image.altText: Postal vote 600x600

props.synopsis: Gender parity in Victorian councils is hoped for next year, but only 40 per cent of candidates are women. So, why aren't people — including men — interested in running?

title.children: 'Makes no sense': Lack of power, wards, time burden blamed for almost 50 uncontested council elections

image.altText: A teenage girl with blonde hair and a red jacket reaches the summit of Manaslu.

props.synopsis: Not many 16-year-olds would happily trek for weeks on end at sky-high altitudes, and in blisteringly cold conditions, to reach a summit so high it's in the "death zone".

title.children: How a 16yo Melbourne schoolgirl set a new record on a Nepalese mountaintop

image.altText: Geam On

props.synopsis: Against some of the biggest players in the world of fragrances, an Australian company managed to convince Lionel Messi they were the right people to launch his new product.

title.children: 'We pinch ourselves all the time': How an Aussie company secured a fragrance deal with superstar Lionel Messi

image.altText: Molly holds a bow and arrow while wearing elf ears. She has long brown hair and a pair of glasses.

props.synopsis: For most of her childhood, Molly preferred to keep to herself. Then she discovered the world of cosplay.

title.children: Molly's love of dragons, potions and elf ears has helped her find a community in her small country town

image.altText: A pink and yellow hue aurora in the night sky with trees in the forefront

props.synopsis: The aurora australis has returned, lighting up the skies in intense colours over southern states. If you missed out on seeing it last night you may get another chance.

title.children: 'Enchanting' aurora display wows photographers and stargazers once again

image.altText: A teen girl sitting in front of a pink wall

props.synopsis: Now 13, Hiba dreams of being able to go to school, like other girls her age. Instead she sits on the side of the road, surrounded by bombed and broken houses, selling handmade bracelets.

title.children: Inside the life of a 13 year-old girl trying to survive 'a war of hell'

image.altText: Foreign minister Penny Wong faces the media in Adelaide. 2024-04-06 10:04:00

props.synopsis: Seats are still available on flights departing on Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

title.children: Australian government no longer scheduling flights out of Lebanon

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers talks National Accounts

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers has warned the foreign crisis could feed directly into the domestic cost-of-living crisis, via the price of oil.

title.children: For ordinary voters, the Middle East crisis remains 'over there' — until it comes to the fuel pump

image.altText: Two women stand outside close together smiling widely, with colourful cement and iron structure behind them.

props.synopsis: While stigma about couples with big age gaps still exists, it's shifting thanks to young people's dissatisfaction with the relationship models they've inherited. And for these happy couples, different ages have proven to be a non-issue.

title.children: A two-decade age gap hasn't got in the way of this couple's happiness, but stigma has threatened to

image.altText: People gather in front of a destroyed building in Lebanon.

props.synopsis: Israel has launched a deadly airstrike on central Beirut, while its ground troops in Lebanon have been accused of firing on the UN peacekeeping headquarters.

title.children: Israel strikes central Beirut, killing 22 and injuring 117 as IDF fires on UN peacekeeper positions, UN force says

image.altText: Seven Network's logo on a building

props.synopsis: Amelia Saw, who worked for the network's Spotlight program, has taken the company to Federal Court alleging breaches of the Fair Work Act.

title.children: Seven asks for 'salacious' court documents to be kept secret after being sued by former journalist

image.altText: Medicinal cannabis vial

props.synopsis: The father of a man who took his own life after being prescribed medicinal cannabis says his family was repeatedly sent more cannabis, despite notifying the telehealth platform of his death. The ABC can reveal the founder of the company has been banned from supplying cannabis and two doctors have been suspended.

title.children: Medicinal cannabis doctors investigated by authorities after suicide and hospitalisation of patients

image.altText: A live sports betting site on a mobile phone, April 24, 2020.

props.synopsis: When the prime minister answered a question about protecting children from gambling harm he gave statistics that mystified experts and advocates. The source of the figures remains a mystery.

title.children: A mystery gambling statistic has entered our debate, and no one knows where it came from

image.altText: A woman looks on with her hands behind her head.

props.synopsis: Interim Matildas coach Tom Sermanni names his squad for matches against Switzerland and Germany, with Sam Kerr still out but young gun Daniela Galic called up for the first time.

title.children: Sam Kerr still out as new era begins for Matildas with squad named for this month's friendlies

image.altText: Man suspended from a cable attached to a helicopter hovering over the ocean , approaching a man holding on an esky in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Clinging to debris, an esky in the ocean and staying put on a boat are some of the many ways Floridians rode out Hurricane Milton,

title.children: How Americans 'hung on for dear life' as Hurricane Milton ripped through Florida

image.altText: A koala inside a small cage

props.synopsis: Conservationists say they are disappointed Transport for NSW made light of a koala wandering through a Sydney train station after it emerged the animal had to be rescued from a home soon after.

title.children: Koala spotted at train station needed second rescue after viral video

image.altText: couple cuddle on bed

props.synopsis: About half of people disclosed, or believed they should disclose, an STI to a partner before having sex, a recent review from the Journal of Sex Research found.

title.children: Tips for disclosing you have an STI, including anonymous ways to share

image.altText: Two men walk through a field on a farm with blue sky.

props.synopsis: ACTU president Michele O'Neil is calling on the government to reform a temporary working visa scheme that prevents workers leaving bad bosses and to blacklist dodgy employers who use migration worker exploitation as a business model.

title.children: A temporary working visa scheme slammed as a 'modern day slavery risk' urgently needs overhauling, advocates say

image.altText: A shoe on the floor of a kitchen is seen from up close

props.synopsis: Ecovacs robot vacuums in multiple US cities were hacked in the space of a few days, with the attacker physically controlling them and yelling obscenities through their onboard speakers.

title.children: Hackers take control of robot vacuums in multiple US cities and abuse owners

image.altText: A woman sitting on a bench, speaking and gesturing.

props.synopsis: The princess joins her husband in Southport, north-west England, to meet the families of several children killed in a stabbing attack there earlier this year.

title.children: Princess Catherine makes surprise appearance in English town rocked by deadly stabbing attack

image.altText: Silhouhette of a woman against a graphic background of red and blue, with a photo of a corridor in the background.

props.synopsis: The workplace safety regulator finds a new centre for women recovering from domestic, sexual and family violence in regional NSW has exposed its workers to "psychological injury", after the departure of most of its frontline staff.

title.children: Staff at Australian-first DV trauma recovery centre raise 'major red flags' over workplace safety

image.altText: a seated woman in a pink floral dress, smiling

props.synopsis: The friends of Lockyer Valley woman Frances Crawford, who was allegedly murdered by her husband, have remembered her as a "heartfelt" person who "would do anything for anybody".

title.children: Mother-of-three Frances Crawford remembered as 'selfless' as husband's murder charge heard in court

image.altText: A composite image of a man and a woman

props.synopsis: The final stretch of a heated election campaign is being marked by a spat over hurricane funding, disinformation, and a surprise announcement from Melania Trump. But will it change the outcome of the race?

title.children: Melania's bombshell, hurricanes, and disinformation: The home stretch of the US race gets chaotic

image.altText: Sean "Diddy" Combs dressed in a suit and bowtie not smiling

props.synopsis: Sean "Diddy" Combs will stand trial on federal sex trafficking and racketeering charges starting on May 5, a US judge has decided.

title.children: Sean 'Diddy' Combs sex trafficking trial set for May

image.altText: jonathan haidt

props.synopsis: American social psychologist Jonathan Haidt tells a gathering of policymakers and parents that Australia should set an example to the world by helping to "slay" the "monsters" created by his home country's social media giants, as state governments and the Commonwealth look to clamp down on largely unfettered access to online platforms among young children.

title.children: Renowned US author urges Australia to 'slay' the world's social media 'monsters', as children open up about harassment

image.altText: Nadal in Brisbane

props.synopsis: Spain's Rafael Nadal, a 22-time grand slam champion, says it was a difficult decision that took him some time, but "in this life, everything has a beginning and an end".

title.children: Rafael Nadal to retire from professional tennis after next month's Davis Cup

image.altText: Photo illustration of autonomous self-driving cars on a highway.

props.synopsis: Time to test how much attention you've been paying to the news!

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Hurricane Milton, Laneway lineups, and is your car watching you?

image.altText: Illuminated logos of Coles and Woolworths outside of each supermarket in a shopping centre.

props.synopsis: The local share market loses ground, and major supermarket chains are grilled over why Tim Tams are cheaper in the UK than in Australia. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Coles, Woolworths grilled over pricing and landbanking by senators

image.altText: A crate of western rock lobsters

props.synopsis: Australian rock lobster exports to China look set to resume by the end of the year, and many are celebrating. Here's what that decision means for industry and consumers alike.

title.children: Australian lobster is back on China's menu. The fishing industry is ecstatic, but consumers may be the ones who pay

image.altText: Kyah Simon of Sydney FC posing for the camera, holding a soccer ball in one hand

props.synopsis: A new course to help community coaches, umpires, participants and volunteers deal with incidents of racism in the moment is hoped to improve local sport.

title.children: 'You're fighting on your own': Focus on combating racism in community sport
